awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Adapting Reading Comprehension Strategies for use in Elementary School Computer Science Instruction to Educate Tomorrow?s Computational Innovators
awd_abstract_narration:
In order to produce a more competitive, computer-literate domestic workforce ready to be computational innovators, this project seeks to improve computer science instruction at the upper elementary school level. It will create strategies for teaching a diverse set of students, including students with learning disabilities, English language learners, and students with a variety of ethnic, gender, and socioeconomic backgrounds. It will draw on decades of research on reading comprehension to drive our exploration into metacognitive learning strategies for computer science. While many computer science educational activities focus on older students, this project addresses the need to enhance computer science education for elementary school students and does it in a way that is accessible and effective for diverse student populations.  The researchers will explore how reading skills, reading comprehension, and computer programming skills can be related. The ultimate goal will be to identify and develop techniques, including teacher and student resources, for learning to program in the early years. The strategies involved in the project support improving computer science instruction and expanding access to computing for all students. 

This project will study skills that are correlated with success in programming, especially as they relate to reading comprehension and metacognitive strategies. It will then modify and pilot-test strategies for use in programming instruction. More specifically, the goals of this project are to: (1) Assess a variety of skills and abilities (e.g. reading comprehension, mathematics, and cognitive skills) to correlate with successfully learning programming. (2) Explore metacognitive strategies used by successful college-level novice programmers. (3) Perform a theoretical analysis of several existing metacognitive learning strategies and how they relate to code comprehension. (4) Develop two promising metacognitive strategies as code comprehension strategies, including teacher modeling and guided instruction resources as well as student resources. (5) Implement new strategies in the classroom to evaluate for usability, fidelity, and impact.  This project represents foundational work in understanding the relationship between non-programming skills and learning programming in upper elementary students, as well as the metacognitive strategies that successful learners employ while reading code during the programming learning process. This research represents the beginning of a rich agenda that strives to better understand how to adapt teaching techniques and learning techniques, not just content, for the elementary school audience. Funding for this project comes from the NSF ECR Program.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of our project was to explore the relationship between effective learning strategies for elementary reading comprehension and programming, design new computing specific learning strategies, and perform initial studies on the usefulness of the new strategies. Our most promising strategy was TIPP&SEE, which is used to help students gain new knowledge and skills  in computer science concepts. Guided by TIPP&SEE, students explore coding through the use of example code. Instead of just providing students with code and expecting them to know how to learn from it. TIPP&SEE outlines a sequence of steps a learner can go follow to learn from example code. First, the learner runs the code, making close observations of how it works. Then the learners inspects the code, making connections between what they observed when running the program and what they see in the code. Finally, the learner makes small, individual changes to the code and reruns the program, closely observing how each change affects how the program runs. Then they can construct their own knowledge about the different code blocks. TIPP&SEE and the reading comprehension strategies that guided its development scaffold processes in ways that model what more expert coders and readers do to accomplish desired outcomes. 

 

There were two significant findings about TIPP&SEE. First, students with below average performance on cognitive assessments performed as well as their peers in the control condition with average cognitive abilities, demonstrating that TIPP&SEE does provide equitable access to the general curriculum. Second, with students at academic risk, because of poverty, multilingualism, disability, and below grade performance in reading and math on state testing, the use of TIPP&SEE narrowed the gap between their performance and the performance of peers without risk factors. 

 

In order to research the effects of using our strategy, we performed a major revision of the San Francisco Unified School District introductory coding curriculum, integrating TIPP&SEE and replacing half of the activities with activities we developed . This curriculum was then used by SFUSD as well as districts around the country. Literacy scaffolds, especially for English Language Learners, were integrated by University of California, Irvine?s team, resulting in the ECforALL curriculum. In addition, our Scratch Encore introductory middle-school curriculum also integrates the TIPP&SEE strategy. These curricula have been downloaded by over 3000 teachers around the world, and hundreds of teachers have taken our EdX online professional development course. Outside of our own curricula, the TIPP&SEE approach is being taught to teachers in several universities in the United States and Europe.
